poem:
Begin the poem below:

I am the steel ribcage of 42,  
waking before sunrise,  
wheels humming a restless heartbeat  
against asphalt veins.  

The city yawns beneath my undercarriage—  
coffee steam curls around my mirrors,  
taxi horns ricochet off concrete canyons.  
I glide through dawn’s purple hush,  
sipping diesel breath,  
ready to scatter strangers like seeds.  

At the river crossing, geese paddle in perfect formation.  
I hum louder, throttle surging—  
no room for waddling diplomats.  
Their plaintive honks dissolve  
inside my engine’s growl.  

But when a wall erupts in color—  
emerald tags, fuchsia drips,  
courting my tired chassis—  
I coast.  
I drink in each swoop of spray paint,  
each defiant flourish,  
like ink on a confession.  

Passengers drift in and out,  
their faces flicker in windows—  
some sleepy, some watchful,  
all part of my choreography.  
I carry laughter and silent grief,  
worn backpacks and grocery bags,  
the sharp tang of summer rain.  

Afternoon finds me weaving  
through gridlocked arteries.  
A siren’s echo ricochets,  
and I swerve—delighted by the unexpected  
like a dancer thrown off rhythm  
yet smiling in mid-step.  

Night unfurls its quiet cloak,  
streetlights drip gold onto my roof.  
I pull to the curb, exhausted yet restless.  
Under flickering neon, I inhale the city’s pulse—  
the tang of fried onions,  
the distant wail of saxophones,  
the sticky breath of secret alleyways.  

I am Route 42,  
neither saint nor villain,  
but a wanderer in steel and spark—  
refusing geese their solemn march,  
pausing for every burst of color  
that dares to claim these walls.  
Tonight, I rest in moonlit slumber,  
dreaming of tomorrow’s hum and roar.
